segments.text: We are talking to Elizabeth Berg and Nadick.
This won't be very—we'll just cover a lot of things, okay?
Some of it, as you saw from that list, is very—well, let's just talk—can you just give me a little biographical background?
Let's start very innocently.
You can tell me a little bit about—
Wow!
You mentioned the fact that you're an army brat, so you've had a peripatetic life, which I'm sure reflects itself on what you've written so far to some degree.
Yeah, particularly in Endurable Goods, which is about an army brat.
That's fine.
I'm just going to put this closer to you, like right there.
Okay?
The closer it is, the better it is for a transcript.
Sure.
So, yeah, that's the deal.
My father was, in fact...
out of the service at the time I was born, which is why I got to be born in Minnesota.
My brother was born in Germany and my sister was born in California.
And then he rejoined, I think I was two or three, and we started moving around like crazy from that time on.
And there were two or three years in which I went to three different schools in that one year.
It was not great.
My father has a whole different perspective on it because he sees it as an opportunity to travel.
And it's true that, you know, I saw Spain and Italy and all that stuff.
But I wanted to be here so that I would know what was on the top ten.
You know, I could care less about going into the catacombs.
I wanted to see the commercials.
I wanted to see what they were wearing and all that stuff.
And so it was sort of lost on me.
And it was very hard to be.
the new girl all the time and not be studying, not having, you know, I was studying something in one school and then I'd come here and they'd be doing Texas history and, you know.
And also knowing that it is impermanent.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
With the almost certain knowledge that you're going to be going someplace else.
Yeah, there's something that interests me a lot about

about that kind of growing up in Army Breath, and that is something that I seem to see in all of them, which is that you seem to be gregarious, very friendly, chatty, you can get along with anybody, you can make a conversation with anyone, but you only let people get so far, and then you stop, because it's too painful to open yourself up to people and then leave, and constantly leave, and all those promises about, I'm going to write you early days,

I remember pulling my eyelash out in one new school and writing my best friend and saying, here's my eyelash, I'm going to write you every day for the rest of my life, and you know, last about three weeks.
Just for biographical purposes, can you tell me your father's name, your mother's name?
My father's name is Arthur Peter Hoff, and my mother's name is H-O-S-S.
And my mother's name is...
Yeah, I call him AP.
Okay.
And my mother's name is Marion Jean, she goes by Jean.
J-E-A-M-N-E.
J-E-A-M-N-E.
Okay.
And you were born in St.
Claude, you said?
Yeah.
Was this while your dad was still in the service?
No, he was in, he came out for a while, and then he decided to re-enlist.
So this would be, you said, 46?
I mean, you're 46 years old, so it was about 1948.
Right.
I was born in 48, yeah.
Okay.
Baby boomer.
Yeah.
So to speak.
Yeah.
And your father was in the Army.
I mean, Army Brad is almost an officer, or was it?
Yeah.
Yeah.
Don't you forget.
Yes.
He was a major when he retired.
Uh-huh.
And the truth is, I never...
knew very much about what he did.
It was not a talkative sharing kind of family environment, for one thing.
And he's not much of a talker anyway, but he had different jobs in artillery and intelligence.
His last job was in recruiting.
And he would wear those play army clothes, you know, he'd come home sometimes in critiques and combat boots and all that.
I used to like to unlace the combat, which is very exciting.
He was out of the service when you were born, but then he went back in again?
Yeah.
Was this around Korea or something like that, or why he was growing up?
Well, let's see, he would have re-enlisted around 50 or 51.
I don't know exactly why he did that, except
My sense is that, yes, exactly.
He loved travel.
I think that it offered him a lot of security, particularly since he knew he could be in 20 years and then retire and have pay or whatever it is that happens.
But he liked that life.
And that married folks that still live?
Mm-hmm.
And they obviously are fans of yours.
I'm sure they read your books.
Uh, yeah, yeah, durable books was a hard one for my father because, um, it was, it was loosely autobiographical.
My father was a pretty scary guy, yeah.
You were anticipating a question here, okay.
Yeah, but, so, um, the truth is that when I wrote that manuscript, um, uh,
I had the first, let's see, the first book I ever wrote came about because I've been writing for magazines a lot, including Terrence Magazine.
And this is all stuff that we want, by the way.
Okay, okay, okay, so I won't feel guilty.
No, no, I mean, if you look at your little list, your little... Okay, well, I didn't see the whole thing.
But anyway... I'll show you when we can.
All right.
We'll make sure we do that.
No, because I don't want you thinking about it.
I just, you know, I mean, it's very... No, no, I... You know what I'm saying?
Yeah.
I hate doing interviews.
The truth is that I will try to weasel out of almost any interview that comes up, except this one, because when Sally told me that PW wanted to do an interview, I said, really?
And I was thinking, hmm, PW or PW?
So I wanted to do this one because it's a big deal.
There's a real bonus getting me, by the way, too, I have to say.
I heard good things about you.
But beyond that, I mean, the payoff is that I write for 23 other newspapers in college towns.
Oh, right, yeah, yeah.
But I just heard that you were really, you know, that I wouldn't, they said, oh, you're really going to like him.
And look what a good start we're off to.
We're going to have vodka in a little while.
I've got brownies coming out of the aisle.
I really do.
I got nervous, so I made brownies.
But I hate doing the news because I feel like everything that I want to say publicly is in my books, which is, you know, the old cliche.
moreover, and more importantly, and biggest, I feel when I'm talking about myself that someone behind me is saying, wow, aren't we fascinated with ourselves?
My, my.
And, you know, don't you think you've said, I'm trapped now?
Isn't it the other person's surgery?
You know, all that stuff.
And then, you know, you're going to say something so completely manane that we'll
Let's go back to the first book.
You had done a lot of magazines.
Let's start at the beginning.
So I was a nurse.
And I loved nursing.
But my children were young.
They were about four and nine when I stopped nursing.
And sometimes they would be just a little bit sick.
They weren't sick enough that I would
feel like I had to call in and say I can't come to work, but I would feel terrible leaving them because they would have a little cold and I wanted to be with them.
Where was this, by the way?
That I was a nurse?
Yeah.
Lots of places, including Leonard Morse, well it was Leonard Morse Hospital, which is right at the end of this block.
It's now Metro West.
I worked at Newton Wellesley Hospital.
I did visiting nursing.
I did, at one point I was working in intensive care.
Oh, they're the best people.
They are the best.
If you ever go to the hospital, get in with the nurses.
Forget about the doctors.
Get in with the nurses.

But anyway, so I was doing intensive care and home nursing, and it was a really wonderful contrast to be in the really high-tech area and then see them at home in their own little jammies and with their phones beside them and their children and all their own things, and it was a kind of access that you're not allowed when you're

in the hospital so I loved doing it but I felt badly about leaving my kids oftentimes and then you know you had to work on your birthday you have to work on Christmas you have to work nights you have to work double shifts all that stuff so I had I thought um I thought because um people had always told me from forever you know you're such a good writer you ought to be a writer
And I wrote, you know, letters and I wrote in journals.
Hi, here's Lisa.
I just wanted to get back to you on... I'll call you back.
Anyway, so... Is that a little red light when I write this going?
Yes.
Okay, great.
Yes, it is.
Okay, so... Okay, don't let me forget what I'm... Okay, so...
I said, okay, I know what I'm going to do.
I'm going to be your writer.
So I sent off, I went and got some magazines that I thought I could perhaps write for, including Parents Magazine.
And I sent off some queries, and Parents Magazine was having, in the issue I bought, there was an essay contest, and you were supposed to write about how you solve some aspects of parenting.
So I wrote a little essay for Parents Magazine, and I sent off queries.
waited for them to, you know, call me and say, oh, you're so wonderful, what have you been?
And so the letters came back to the queries that said, don't be ridiculous, don't ever call us again, you know, more or less.
And I said, well, fine.
So, and they were, I mean, I did everything wrong.
It was brown ink and everything, you know, because I thought it would be pretty to have brown scripts on my... How old were you about this time?
Really?
And let me just interject, you said people thought you wrote well, I mean did you write for publication?

No, no, this was just friends, you know, and in school, and in school, because I wrote letters, I mean I always wrote, from the time I was a little girl I wrote, I used to try to write poetry when I was a little girl, and I sent a poem off, I sent my first poem off at nine years old
and it was rejected by American Girl magazine, American Girl magazine.
And I got the rejection letter and I was devastated.
For one thing, my poem rhymed, and I couldn't imagine why they would have all this free verse and not take my rhyming poem.
Was it a form letter?
Yes.
The last line of my poem was, the beauty enchantment now was broken.
And she remembers it after a week.
I remember the whole thing.
But anyway, I really felt terrible.
I was so embarrassed, and I went in my room and I cried, and I didn't submit anything for 25 years.
But anyway, so I... It's a great life.
You're doing very well.
You're making my job very easy here.
Anyway, so I got the re-diff for the queries, and said, fine.
I keep thinking you're going to say somebody else or something else when you start with that.
Yeah, yeah.
Not me.
So then we moved.
We were living in South Bend.
We moved to Newton, and I got a letter one day, and shortly after we'd moved, it was from Parents' Agency.
I thought actually it was a solicitation for a subscription, which I did not want.
So I threw it away, and I thought, well, but it's not, yeah.
So I opened it because it was a different kind of envelope.
I threw out checks like this.
Where do you live?
Where do you keep your garbage?
I can check from 30 different newspapers and you never know.
It looks like a stupid computer.
You have to open all your mail.
My wife says, you don't touch the mail anymore.
I open all the mail.
I'll take care of this.
I have tons of junk and I routinely throw stuff away without opening it.
I do too.
I do too.
But anyway, when I opened it, what it was, was a letter from Parents 19 saying, which I still have, is that?
Saying, congratulations, it took us many months to call through the thousands of entries we received, but you are a winner, you know, the ParentWise contest.
And the ParentWise?
It was called the ParentWise contest.
One word?
Like wise, parent, you know, parent-wise.
One word or two words.
One.
Okay.
ParentWise is one word.
Right.
Right.
So, um...
They had chosen three people to win a prize of $500.
What happened, actually, is that they ran the other things, like the prize winners of, you know, here are our efforts, but they held mine, and then they just ran mine as an article.
It was in 1985, I think, and so I couldn't believe it.
I couldn't
And so I looked at the check for about a year, you know, I just kept looking at it and looking at it.
And then I said, okay, I'm going to go spend it.
So I went to my favorite store, which was called Limited Edition, and I bought stupid stuff.
I bought a purse and jewelry and a scarf.
I mean, nothing that I needed.
And not even things that I was particularly crazy about.
It's just that I had this money that I was going to go wildly spend.
And then when I came home, I put all my stuff on the dining room table, and then I started crying.
And I said, look what I bought.
I could have bought a Mix Master if I'd thought about this.
I could have bought a Mix Master.
So I said, if I ever sell another article, I'm getting that Mix Master.
So I started selling articles, in fact, regularly to Parents Magazine.
Parents Magazine bought, I think, almost everything.
I sensed it real well.
It was a very happy combination because... Starting in 86.
Yeah, because the editor at the time had children, my children's age.
She is so fabulous.
Elizabeth Crow is her name, and she's now the editor-in-chief at Manusel.
She's a very wonderful, bright, generous, open woman who's not afraid
to say to someone who's brand new, you've got a lot of talent and I'm going to, you know, and I'm going to use you.
I mean, she didn't, she didn't make me feel, she just made me feel like I was a professional or something.
So then I started writing for a lot of other magazines, and then I, well, I also was diagnosed with cancer in 85, and I, and I was.
Is it above the same time you sent in that?
It is.
I had just, I had just,

sold um you know that essay thing and i just started and and she had and she had uh i had told her i had another one that i wanted to send her and and she said fine did you tell me the title of the first piece that you sent in that one that you remember it but it's always involved
It was about, ironically enough, it was about leaving work to stay home with your children, how that was a fine thing to do.
And of course, then I immediately went back to work, because it didn't, but anyway.
But let me ask, did you write this prior to your diagnosis or after your diagnosis?
No, I had not been diagnosed.
I was working part-time as a nurse.
I was beginning to sell articles to Parents Magazine, and then I was diagnosed.
I remember calling... No, no.
Tell me when I'm... You brought up diagnosis, and I see it in here.
Can you tell me what it was, or do you prefer not telling me what the diagnosis is?
No, I'll tell you what it is.
I had had a rash right here on my stomach for a number of years.
Okay.
But just tell me basically, was it skin cancer?
No, this is why I have to tell you what it was.
I had a rash.
I thought it was nothing.
It was treated with steroids and so on.
It was finally biopsy.
And I said, why are you biopsying it?
Are you looking for basal cell carcinoma, which of course is skin cancer?
And they said, no, we're looking for mycosis fungoides, which is a lymphoma and is incurable.
And that's not the way that I was told, by the way.
I'm shortening it.
But you're a health professional.
You know what's going on.
What happened was I went to one doctor who said, I want to biopsy this.
And I said, what for?
And she said, this was here in Framingham.
She said, I'm not going to tell you what for because if I tell you what for, you're going to go home and look it up and you're going to freak out.
And we don't know what it is.
So I said, well, now you have to tell me what you're looking for.
So she told me mycosis fungoides.
I went home and looked it up and freaked out.
So that biopsy came back negative.
What happens with MS is it's very hard to diagnose.
You can get a lot of negative biopsies before you get a pocket.
The rash persisted and spread.
I had it biopsied yet again.
I was at home.
My kids were four and nine.
They each had a friend over.
Howard was at work.
This doctor called me and said,
We got your biopsy back.
And I said yes.
And I was wishing you'd hurry up and say it's fine.
Just use steroids.
And he said, it looks like something's going on in your skin.
And I said, uh-oh.
And I sat down on the bed.
I remember I had my little apron on.
And I said, is it MF?
And he said, yes.
And I said, my co-system.
Isn't that the ugliest thing?
Is it in here?
Will I be able to spell this?
M-Y-C-O-S-I-S, F-U-N-G-O-I-D-E-S.
It means looks like fungus, which it does.
It looks like a fungal kind of graphic.
So… I won't make a big deal out of this, but… Yeah, don't make a big deal of it.
It'll maybe be one paragraph.
Well, the thing that it did… But it is pertinent to the writing that… It certainly is, yeah.
And I… And so I… Which is what I'm fundamentally interested in.
I talked to him for a little bit.
I called Howard who came home immediately.
He took a few days off from work.
I took off from work.
I went to the hospital library and I researched this disease and I saw and I got a million zeroes.
Are we in 86 though?
And this is after the Parents Magazine?
Yeah, I had just begun.
I called Elizabeth Crown and said, I'm going to be a little late sending this article.
I just got diagnosed with a curable cancer.
C-R-O-W.
She's wonderful.
So I was taking my kids to the beach.
It was almost Jenny's birthday.
In fact, it was 10 years ago on the 8th.

So I was taking my kids to the beach and when they were playing in the water, I was reading these horrible articles about statistics about when people died and looking at these graphic photos of people in fourth stage disease.
It was the worst time in my life ever.
But the day I found...
You're about the age of Lainey in the book.
Of course, it's her husband.
Yeah, yeah.
But the day that it happened, this just will, I think, let you know briefly what my attitude about this is the evening of the day that I was diagnosed.
I told the kids that I was going to take them berry picking over to a friend's house.
And we went berry picking over to that friend's house.
And I came back and I made pies.
And they were the best pies I ever made.
And my husband said, which was the most wonderful thing, he said, do you want to do the I Ching?
And I said, yes, I want to do the I Ching.
And I didn't know how to do it, but he knows how to do it.
I know how to do it now, though.
And the thing that I got back was molting of the skin.
What's the I Ching on it?
The I Ching is the Chinese Book of Changes.
Oh, okay, so he asked you to... You get these, you toss coins six times and you get these little hexagrams, scissors back, and then you look it up and here's what you've got.
I've always had incredible respect, you know, woo-woo mysticism around this kind of thing.
But I got molting of the skin, okay?
And I said, okay, well, that's a good sign.
And I felt better.
And nothing else made me feel better, because I don't have any traditional religion.
And I didn't really trust anything that I read in articles, and I didn't trust my doctor.
I just feel like we know so little, really.
So that made me feel terrific.
And what happened in the weeks subsequent to that diagnosis was I found out that the
mean time of survival for a patient's diagnosis is 10 years.
That's the mean time of survival.
And I had very early stage disease.
And he was telling me, it runs again.
You can get radiation therapy, you can do chemo therapy, you can do local applications of steroids, you can use light therapy, electron beam therapy.
It's so confusing, and I ended up, I went to Stanford University, I went to Temple University, I consulted everybody I could consult with.
I ended up, and I quit nursing because I thought I was going to do electron beam therapy and aggressive chemotherapy, and I did not, but I thought I was going to do that.
But that's why you kept, so you quit nursing about?
I quit nursing because I didn't know what I was going to be doing.
But three things are happening at the same time here.
It started to write, yeah.
It started to write, you've been diagnosed with cancer and you quit nursing.
This was all happening about 1986 or so.
Right, right.
So I… This will show up as one sentence in two, by the way.
That's fine.
That's fine.
It just, it was a real wake-up call, as you might expect, because what I was told by a badly misinformed doctor was I had about five years.
And then when I found out that the mean time of survival was ten years according to NCI statistics, I went back to him with that information and you know what he said?
He said, well, you have your statistics and I have mine.
So I promptly found another doctor who shared M&Ms with me and who saw life a little bit more like I do.
Did he say it smugly?
Yeah, because he had been called on something.
The fact was he was ill-prepared and he
So at that point, they're dismissive, aren't they?
Yeah.
Sound familiar?
I mean, you know a little bit about the business.
Yeah, that's right.
Yeah, he was embarrassed because he hadn't done his homework.
Anyway, I never went back to nursing because I started selling articles like crazy for magazines, and I got to stay home with my kids, I got to write
for a living, which I love doing.
Was there a theme to what you were writing?
Oh no, I wrote about my kids.
Their first person, personal experience pieces.
And then I began selling to other magazines as well.
Can you name some of them?
Name some of the magazines.
Oh, Parents Magazine, I wrote for Woman's Day, I wrote for Family Circle, I wrote for Red Book, Ladies Home Journal,
So there's a specific readership?
Women's magazines, yeah.
Okay.
And there were personal experience pieces.
And then I began writing fiction.
And at about what point?
When?
I guess about, I guess just two or maybe three years into it.
About 1990 or so?
I mean, I can tell you exactly, but it would take some time.
Somewhere around there, yeah.
We were going to say about.
About is a wonderful word.
Yeah, about.
About.
I can look it up later tonight.

But I didn't feel that I could ever write a book, because it seemed to me that it would be trying to keep track of little puppy dog's tales, you know, that you just do... How could you ever... A book meaning a novel.
A novel.
I mean, how could you ever, you know, you start it and then you write so many pages, how could you ever remember what was at the beginning?
I mean, it's really impossible.
I couldn't do it.
I didn't want to do it.
I would never, ever do it.
So...
Somebody called Parents Magazine in, let's see now, 91, looking, they said, who's a really good writer?

Because I want to do a book on family traditions, and I want a really good writer to, you know, I have readers that I just want to do, and I've got the whole, you know, it's all set, I just need to write.
So they said, oh, this is her.
She's so very popular.
So she called me and said, want to do this book, and I said.
Was it an agent or a publisher?
No, a book developer.
A book developer.
Yeah.
Do you know about book developers?
No.
They're sort of like middle people.
They're like hit hunters, so to speak, right?

Well, they arrange for the art and some of the mechanics, which I don't really know about, and so they save the publisher money because they arrange for all this other stuff, and then they find a writer and they put together a package.
Exactly.
And they get half.
It happens a lot.
It happens a lot.
Yes, it is.
And of course, now when I think about it, I think, particularly since in this case, Rudolf Digest ended up paying for all the other stuff.
So the book developer, please keep this off
the record, but the developer did very well on that deal.
She really cleaned up.
Because I changed it.
I made a new table of contents.
It was really much more my book.
But with all due respect, it was the book developer's idea.
Exactly, exactly.
And it did give you the exact amount of publishing.
Not really, as it turns out.
I'll tell you why not.
So this book was titled, and I did see it.
Family traditions.
And when we're talking family traditions, we're talking about what, like Hanukkah, stuff like that?
Yes, those traditions, but also...
honoring things in ordinary days.
You see a theme beginning to emerge here.
Oh, God, I don't know.
You can look at the table of contents.
Well, we'll show it to me before I go, so I guess it's still in print.
Yeah, still in print.
It just came out of the paperback.
Well, that's important that P.W.
wants to know that letter.
So why don't you just leave it here and I'll take a look at it.
So anyway, I told her, no, I did not want to write that book because, first of all, I

I didn't think I was a book writer, and secondly, although I would love to be, but secondly, I didn't have any traditions, and my family was not a great, you know, not rich in tradition, let me say simply.
So she said, well, let me send you a proposal, and just take a look at it and see what you think.
She sent me the proposal, and she had that most seductive of things on there, Family Traditions by Elizabeth Berg.
And I thought, well, you know, maybe I could do it.
And then I'd at least have a book.
It would be a thing that people could hold in their hands and bring in the bathtub.
And, you know, it would be really wonderful to have a book.
So I said I would do it.
It was an enormous amount of research, not like yours, I'm sure, but a lot of research for me.
Can I borrow this, by the way, and I'll send it back to you?
Sure.
And I think it's a worthwhile book.
I think it turned out pretty nicely.
It was a pain in the butt to write.
It just made me crazy because I like, no matter what I'm doing, whether I'm in the intensive care unit or making dinner, I like to have fun.
So I wasn't having fun.
It wasn't enough fun.
How about the book did well, though?
It did very well, yeah.
It wasn't freeing enough, and I wanted to pull at that most creative part of myself, and this was, in fact, restricting me.
So what I did was I said, all right, look, you have to write this book because you said you'd do it.
So you write this book, but every day on Tuesday you can write whatever you want.
because I had my writer's group on Wednesday.
So what I would bring to my writer's group was fiction, which I allowed myself to write on Tuesday, which became Durable Goods.
So I sent my agent— This was 1992 when it was published.
Right.
That was published in 1992, and I began writing Durable Goods.
Did it appear as a hardcover first?
Yeah.
Want to see the hardcover?
It looked just like that.
How long did it take you to write it?
I don't know, six months or so.
Every Tuesday I would just write durable goods.
And durable goods came out like pouring water out of the pitcher.
Like throwing up.
I would sit down with the typewriter and type continuously.
Now, that was kind of a departure, wasn't it, from the essays that you've been writing, the pieces, the durable goods?
Do you think of it?
I always write really fast.
I don't mean in terms of the production, I mean in terms of the writing, the story, the thematic stuff.
It was, yes, it was, yes, because it was a novel, for one thing, and it took its own… But I mean thematically and…
the kind of stories that you've been writing for the magazines.
Yes, yes.
It's your company voice that you use writing for women's magazines.
I absolutely had my heart in what I was doing, but it's a different kind of writing.
You can't be as loose as you are in a novel.
And in durable goods, I just let myself go.
And I didn't know that
It was really going to be a novel.
I just had this thing inside.
It's like an irritation.
It's like you feel something under your skin and you pick away at it.
You need to get that thing out, you know.
And I never know with any of my books, in fact, what it is exactly that I'm going to need to say.
I start with a feeling and then whatever happens, happens.
A couple of things.
Did you have an agent or were you strictly with the book development?
I did have an agent because I had… You did or you did not?
I did have an agent because what happened was I had sold these fiction stories and I had started a novel.
It was not Durable Goods.
I had started another novel.
That novel was… Which I showed… I was also doing television at that time because I was doing…
video essays for special report television.
And so my little career was beginning to grow, and I was getting these contracts, and I sort of didn't know.
It felt like things were going to start happening more, and I knew that I was not able to handle that myself.
So I asked Elizabeth Crow for the names of agents, and she gave me the names of agents.
I made appointments with two of them, and I liked them both, but I chose Lisa Bancoff at ICM.
And that's who you're still with.

And one of the reasons that that book is so important to me is that there it is, that if there was ever anything I ever wanted to do as a writer, it was to be able to say, look at this, and have someone say, I see it, you know, I see it now.
And, you know, I... Actually, is it just being... Yes, I mean, just that I wanted... I remember being a...

I don't know, I guess I was six or seven or something, and my mother was going to the bank, and I got out of the car with her, and there was a man sitting on the ground, and he didn't have legs, you know, they'd been cut off, and he was sitting on his blanket, and he had his cup, and he was asking for money, and I couldn't believe my eyes.
I had never seen him.
I had never seen anything bad happen to anybody, I guess.
And he was smiling and I got in the car and I burst into tears.
I couldn't believe it.
I felt so bad for him.
And my mother didn't know what to do.
I think I put this in one of my books.
But anyway, so she gave me some money.
She gave me a quarter or something and I put it in his cup and he said, thank you little lady.
And I said, but look how he is.
Look how he is.
